Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Acetaminophen for Prevention of Acute Kidney Injury in Cardiac Surgery

Intervention.evidence: 7,833 receiving acetaminophen and 3,750 in the control group

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess whether perioperative acetaminophen administration reduces the risk of postoperative AKI in adult cardiac surgery patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of postoperative AKI, measured during the hospital stay.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation methods and allocation concealment were not consistently reported across studies.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding of outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians varied.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 11,583 patients were included, with 7,833 receiving acetaminophen and 3,750 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Acetaminophen administration was associated with a lower incidence of AKI [OR 0.62 (95% CI 0.40–0.97), P = 0.04].

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The study was registered under PROSPERO (CRD42024514111).

Funding.evidence: There was no funding source for this study.
